subject: Re: [junit] Re: TestUtil: By Example
msgSnippet: ... Yes ... Interesting - I was really just pointing out that PMD has code to detect the use of javadoc tags and uses them like attributes. ... As I outlined
messageBody:
On 2/3/06, Marvin Toll <MarvinToll@...> wrote:
> > Thanks - honestly the idea is stolen from PMD.
> > Its what they use to
> > replace attributes (in Java 1.4) so you can supress individual
> > warnings. I bet that you could get the code to the job there.
>
> Are you referring to PMD - the source code analyzer?

Yes

>
> This reference points to the possible convergence of unit testing
> and source code analysis. In a limited sense - this is the notion
> of Verification Facilitation - interrogating a code base through
> convergence of the two approaches.

Interesting - I was really just pointing out that PMD has code to
detect the use of javadoc tags and uses them like attributes.

>
> > I also wonder if you've considered trying to some automated
> arguement
> > checking? Test that methods either accept interesting params: null,
> > "", -1, Integer.MAX_VALUE, .... or throw the appropriate argument
> > exception.
> >
>
> This is very interesting - and the scope could go beyond simply
> accessor methods. For instance, the application chronicled
> in "TestUtil: By Example" contains about 5,000 methods (~3,000 are
> accessors). It might be useful to have a list of which of those
> 5,000 signatures, that include a parameter of type Object, do not
> throw an exception for a null argument. The list could be organized
> by accessor and non-accessor methods.

As I outlined in more detail in my reply to Cedric - thats exactly
what I'm thinking. Currently we encourage developers to write tests
that pass in null, emptyString, etc to test/illustrate the boundary
conditions in their code. It would be very helpful to automate some of
that. BTW This is part of the value that Agitar offers.

>
> > If you're interested I could flesh out the idea some more.

Damn now I'm on the hook.

Cheers
Mark
